title: Wednesday, 20th June, 2018

Ocado Group PLC (OCDO:LSE): Last: 987.40, up 38.6 (+4.07%), High: 1,016, Low: 948.80, Volume: 779.55k
Paper Chase I can resist anything, except temptation.
Swedish Chef BAE? I thought tanks had a bloody great gun on the top. https://www.ft.com/content/19b523a6-7454-11e8-aa31-31da4279a601
11:17 am
BE11:17am

Peel Hunt has put out a foreshadow of its tech conference next week with one of the more bullish notes I've seen in recent times.

BE11:17am

The Microsoft of Retail

BE11:17am

Yeah.

Soundbuy Has SSP Group +2.8% been the recipient of some grey? Quick out the blocks this am., and a third of the daily vols by 9.30......
Bryan Good morning guys, according to a Spanish media Roche would be thinking of buying Tesaro after the purchase in Foundation Medicine. can it be true?
11:18 am
BE11:18am

And it gets even more exciting from there. The argument begins with a premise that Ocado can deliver fruit and veg so it can deliver everything.

BE11:19am

Then it moves onto how Ocado wants to be like Microsoft, all open standards and common availability .....

BE11:20am

..... rather than locked-down and propitiatory, because that's only used by loser companies like ,,, [checks notes] ,,,, Apple.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

From there, we get silly numbers. Trillions of revenue type numbers.

BE11:21am

The top 100 store-based retailers around the world made an aggregate US$3.4tr in revenue in FY16. Around 2.6% or US$89bn of which is Capex. Given that we believe store-based retail will continue to decline, over the medium term this is addressable for Ocado.

BE11:21am

Microsoft! Of! Retail!

baffles Not all store based retail can afford robots
11:21 am
BE11:22am

Whilst we used the example of Windows, which currently has a market share of more than 80%, and believe there is no reason why Ocado couldn’t reach that potential, we ground our assumptions in conservatism. With Ocado’s current model, it only provides the mechanical handling equipment (MHE) and the software clients need to provide the customer fulfilment centre (CFC). Therefore, we have assumed that of the US$89bn total Capex estimate, 60% will be maintained for CFC acquisitions (on average, given that CFCs won’t be acquired every year), leaving a potential fulfilment cost allocation of US$35bn, 40%. Assuming Ocado can hit 30% share, this is a revenue opportunity of US$11bn or £8bn. This could range from £0.3bn to £44.0bn if we sensitise Ocado’s market share (base case = 30%, ranging from 5% to 80%) and the amount of cash is freed up from reduced infrastructure spending (base case = 40%, ranging from 10% to 80%). We assume this is the state of play for Ocado in 15 years’ time.

Pharma On Ocado delivering anything, was looking for Dulux gloss paint, and they had the best price. Do seem to be branching out.
BE11:22am

VV75 This "analysis" of the grocery market opportunity smells like the kind crypto afficionados usually spout.
BE11:24am

So, 30% market share of .... [checks notes] .... total global retailer capex in ..... [checks notes] .... 15 years time.

Pharma Surely 80% is impossible. For all the deals they have struck to date, exclusivity has been a constant theme. Limits them to 20-30%, even if they always sign the largest player in the market.
Badger How do you get a percentage of cash freed up expressed in billions? (first column of note)?
11:24 am
BE11:25am

.... on a 30% EBITDA margin and 75% free cash flow conversion. Long run tech EV/FCF multiple of 20x by .... 2033. Stick in a WACC of 7% and you get a £10bn valuation on Ocado's robot arms.

BE11:25am

Bit hypey maybe? No! Because they've got the Gartner Hype Curve .....

BE11:25am

Otter Hello Friends

Appreciated this well written piece too. https://www.ft.com/content/a41df112-7080-11e8-92d3-6c13e5c92914

Therefore, we're ascending the Slope of Enlightenment towards the Plateau of Productivity. QED, mate.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

As for SSP, as has already been pointed out on the right, it does seem to be on the back of the Autogrill stuff yesterday.

BE11:33am

La Repubblica interview with Edizione CEO Patuano

BE11:34am

And not really saying anything out of line with what's been said before. Here's a summary from Auerbach Grayson.

11:34 am
BE11:34am

On AGL, no big novelties emerged but we underline: ‐Food business is a sector that the holding likes ‐AGL is ready to act as a consolidator in the US where the market is extremely interesting and still fragmented. However there are not big tickets AGL is trading at 2018‐19 Adj.PE=23‐21x vs SSP at 28‐25x. On CLNX, Edizione has reiterated its confidence on the Management team, the sector structural trends and the M&A opportunities. In addition, Mr Patuano confirmed that Edizione is interested in bringing‐in a minority strategic partner (sovereign fund, pension fund, insurance etc.) in a vehicle that invests in Tower. Overall, Edizione reiterated that it has available funding to support the growth of its main investee companies and does not rule‐out the entrance in new sectors.

BE11:35am

The SSP-Autogrill merger idea is, as we've said a thousand times, popular among some in the sellside. We've had no indication whatsoever that it's gone beyond that though.

bones30 Everyone seen the pictures of the Gigatent?
undefined
11:36 am
BE11:37am

Oh, and while we're tidying up old themes -- there seems to be quite a lot of Bunge-Glencore noise again this morning.

Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 384.85, up 13.15 (+3.54%), High: 386.75, Low: 374.00, Volume: 19.78m
BE11:40am

Don't think there's been anything reported in the regular press, though given the noise levels I'd be unsurprised to see something pop up outside the mainstream, where checks and balances are a bit looser.

11:40 am
undefined
BE11:41am

Let's get back to semi-useful stuff. What about Sirius?

Sirius Minerals PLC (SXX:LSE): Last: 32.66, up 1.24 (+3.95%), High: 33.30, Low: 32.28, Volume: 10.10m
Tsetse Alan Sugar
11:41 am
BE11:41am

Another offtake agreement, this one with Intercontinental Trade DMCC Dubai.

BE11:41am

350ktpa

BE11:42am

Shore Capital's shop here. They can sum up what's been said.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

Sirius had been looking to execute c.2Mtpa of incremental agreements in 2018, of which today’s agreement represents a significant 17.5% of that. Furthermore, Sirius’s aggregate peak contracted sales volume now stands at 4.7Mtpa (previously: 4.4Mtpa). Another three or four similar-sized deals would take Sirius into the 6-7Mtpa target range to support the Stage 2 debt financing (for which Sirius hopes to obtain initial lender commitments in mid-2018, towards execution in late 2018).

The 7-year agreement with Dubai-headquartered ITL sees volumes rising to 350ktpa in Year 4, and gives ITL exclusive marketing rights into Nigeria. Nigeria happens to be the largest market in West Africa (and is a key market for fertiliser growth in the region), and ITL is amongst the largest suppliers of fertiliser into that country, with access to distribution and logistics infrastructure (including storage, port concessions and NPK blending facilities).

The agreement’s pricing mechanism is linked to an undisclosed product benchmark, which according to Sirius is consistent with the existing portfolio of agreements. We are hopeful that once a few more contracts have been announced, Sirius will be able to unveil a higher average price than the US$145/t disclosed in late 2016. If this proves the case, it should be very positive for the share price (less in the way of contracted volumes would be required to support the Stage 2 financing; average received prices could be expected to be higher due to the steep discounts required to secure take-or-pay agreements; NPV would therefore be significantly boosted).

Sirius also reported that it continues to make good progress on all aspects of its paradigm-shifting North Yorkshire polyhalite project, and that it is in “active discussions” with potential customers in other key markets such as Europe, India and Brazil.

Shore Capital last visited the project in early May 2018, as of which time Sirius remained on time and on budget to deliver the key milestones that are first polyhalite and commercial production. We have previously opined that there will almost always be delays in projects of such magnitude as Sirius’s, and noted that the company has been doing the right thing in seeking and attempting to capitalise on opportunities to accelerate activities where possible. While Sirius is currently at development stage and still some years from becoming a cash flow-generating company, we believe that an investment in Sirius should become progressively de-risked and enjoy significant value uplift as it advances towards production.

Mr Diamond Anything on Footasylum - recent car crash IPO
BE11:45am

Seems quite a polarising stock, Sirius. The analyst trip last month doesn't seem to have settled concerns among some in the market about viability.

Soundbuy Footasylum....................JD Sports +5%, none to sure why........
BE11:47am

And without pricing specifically defined on the offtake agreements it's difficult to put aside the worry that it's perhaps overly focused on appeasing lenders and raising Stage 2 cash.

11:47 am

@Soundbuy, Barclays shoving JD Sports.

Soundbuy Oh...........ta
BE11:48am

Think they were suspended because they were advisers on the US acquisition. Now not.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

Sorry about the formatting here. Barclays is a pain in the butt.

BE11:50am

As jd sPORTS’ first foray into the notoriously challenging uS market, the finish Line acquisition undoubtedly carries substantial execution risk. however, we believe the company has significant support from key brands (most notably Nike⁄adidas) and WILL TAKE A PRUDENT ‘TEST-and-LEARN’ approach to this new market. furthermore, jD’s success or failure in the uS is not the only driver of the story: while important for sentiment and substantial in terms of revenues (c25$ of fFFI20 group revs), we expect finish Line to contribute ,10$ of group EBIT. FIe therefore view the continued expansion of the core business as the fundamental driver, and we still see room for upgrades here. Stepping back from the deal and consensus estimates, we think jD Sports is well-placed in the increasingly exclusive world of athletic retailing, where leading brands essentially determine the winning retailers by allocating more exclusive product to them. jD shares have regained favour recently (+11$ since 30 May vs. fTSE all share 0$), but we still see substantial upside potential at 15x 12M forward p⁄E. FIe reinstate our rating at OFI with a 510p pT.

BE11:51am

As for Footasylum -- profit warning somewhat under-reported yesterday due to Debenhams being the more recognisable name to news editors.

11:52 am
BE11:53am

We've talked a bit in the past about how the market for trainers is dividing between the good (JD Sports etc) that get the A-grade premium sneakers in exclusive colourways and all that junk ......

BE11:53am

............. and the rest. Footasylum looks to be "the rest".

#REF! Bit late today but a long term WACC of 7% (if QE ever stops) is.... not right.. given level of execution risk and uncertainty
Swedish Chef Sneakers? Butt? Am I in the USA? Don’t see any crying kids though...
BE11:54am

Course, with only two dominant plimsole suppliers out there, might this kind of very restrictive distribution be something the EU competition bods look at? I don't know. Probably not.

11:54 am
BE11:55am

Peel Hunt's Jonathan Pritchard is the go-to analyst on kicks.

BE11:55am

We have long felt that the changes of approach from the likes of Nike and adidas when it comes to product allocation would cause problems medium and long term for companies like Footasylum.

BE11:56am

The manufacturers’ retailer lists have already been culled as they accentuate going direct to consumer and that trend will only continue, with no more than a handful of global retail names ending up “inside the tent”.

Dec69 - Skeptic Interesting reading about the offtake partners, has anyone researched them?
11:57 am
BE11:58am

We have no doubt that JD will be on this list

BE11:58am

(especially now the Finish Line deal puts it on a global standing) but Footasylum may find that its access to the cool product files is restricted over time. Days like today won’t help. We also have concerns about how Footasylum scores on social media: its engagement of customers on Instagram remains poor and we need more evidence that the increased marketing spend will be going in the right places. There is still plenty to like about the brand and its disruptive nature, but there are increasingly more questions than answers.

BE11:58am

So:

11:58 am
BE11:58am

With a following wind, FA could deliver 6p of EPS in FY20. The arguments for a growth multiple here are in tatters so we’ll say it deserves a sector PE, which means a TP of 80p and a Reduce rec.
